newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel says sound EMU stability pact top priority.
newsitem.headline: Waigel says sound EMU stability pact top priority.

text.p: German finance minister Theo Waigel said on Monday that it would be better to wait for a good result on the proposed European stability pact than to move too quickly and have an unfavourable result.
"It would be better to wait for a good result, rather than going too quickly," Waigel told journalists at the launch party for the flotation of Deutsche Telekom.
Asked if he thought an agreement on the stability pact would come before the end of the year, Waigel said it would be good if that was the case, "but we are not under pressure."
Waigel says sound stability pact top priority

The stability pact, proposed by Waigel about a year ago, is aimed at ensuring that European nations forming a single European currency will retain tough fiscal policies which will ensure a stable Euro, the future European currency.

At a meeting of European economic and finance ministers last week, Germany appeared to block agreement on such a pact by insisting on stiff fines for countries that fail to keep the lid on budget deficits after the start of currency union.
Germany's tough stance in Brussels fuelled speculation that Bonn wants to delay agreement on a stability pact until 1998 when it is clear who will join European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).

The finance minister told a German magazine over the weekend that if a satisfactory agreement on the stability pact could not be agreed, negotiations would have to continue after the EU summit in Dublin in December.
